title: 111_hr3382
content: The "Home Improvements Revitalize the Economy Act of 2009" or the "HIRE Act of 2009" aims to address the economic losses in the home furnishing and building products market. It highlights the significant job losses in this sector and proposes deductions for purchases of personal use building products and home furnishings to stimulate the economy. The "Home Improvements Revitalize the Economy Act of 2009" proposes deductions for purchases of qualified building products and home furnishings for individuals to stimulate the economy. The maximum deduction is $2,000 for joint returns and $1,000 for other cases, with a doubling of the limitation for products meeting environmental standards. The "Home Improvements Revitalize the Economy Act of 2009" offers deductions for purchases of qualified building products and home furnishings meeting recognized environmental standards. The dollar limitation is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The tax code sets limits on deductions for qualified building products and home furnishings based on the taxpayer's gross income. The applicable limitation varies depending on filing status, with a rounding rule for amounts not multiples of $10. The tax code limits deductions for qualified building products and home furnishings based on gross income and filing status. Qualified products include building materials and furnishings for a taxpayer's principal residence, excluding electronics, appliances, housewares, and decorations. The tax code allows deductions for building products and home furnishings for a taxpayer's principal residence, excluding electronics, appliances, housewares, and decorations. Labor costs for onsite preparation and installation are included in the cost. The deduction does not apply to expenses incurred after December 31, 2011. The tax code sections 199(d)(2)(A), 219(g)(3)(A)(ii), and 221(b)(2)(C)(i) are amended to include "224," after "222," and "933, and 224" after "933." Section 469(i)(3)(F)(iii) is also amended to include "222, and 224." The table of sections for part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 is updated accordingly. SEC. 4. CREDIT FOR PURCHASES OF PERSONAL USE BUILDING PRODUCTS AND HOME FURNISHINGS. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2008. The tax code allows individuals a credit of 20% on the cost of qualified building products and home furnishings, up to $500 for joint filers ($250 for others). The credit is subject to an adjusted gross income limitation and products meeting environmental standards may have a higher limit. The tax code allows a 20% credit on the cost of qualified building products and home furnishings, subject to income limitations. Labor costs for onsite preparation are included in the cost. The section does not apply to expenses incurred after December 31, 2011. The tax code offers a 20% credit for purchases of building products and home furnishings for resale, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2008. The tax code provides a 10% credit, up to $10,000, for purchases of qualified building products and home furnishings for resale. The definition includes tangible personal property used in personal residences, with exceptions. Controlled groups are treated as a single employer for this credit. The tax code allows for a 10% credit on purchases of building products and home furnishings for resale, with controlled groups treated as a single taxpayer. The credit is part of the general business credit and is refundable. The tax code provides a 10% credit for building products and home furnishings for resale under section 45R. Special rules apply to this credit, including separate application of sections 45R and 39, adjustments for the tentative minimum tax, and limitations on the credit amount. The tax code provides a 10% credit for building products and home furnishings for resale under section 45R. Special rules apply to this credit, including adjustments for the tentative minimum tax and limitations on the credit amount. Additionally, paragraph (1) (as modified by subclause (II)) shall be treated as a credit under subpart C. The tax code offers a 10% credit for building products and home furnishings for resale under section 45R, effective for taxable years ending after December 31, 2008.
